properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for more thunderstorm development early this evening. While the risk of severe thunderstorms has diminished significantly there is a chance of thunderstorm redevelopment. Should thunderstorms develop they may be accompanied by wind gusts near 90 km/h. Any thunderstorm development will weaken through the evening. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-07-20T04:59:48-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm weather is expected. Time span: Monday through Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over central and northeastern Newfoundland for the next couple of days. The warmest conditions are expected to occur over most areas on Tuesday. Temperatures are forecast to turn slightly cooler over all areas later this week. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-07-20T11:16:18-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event ending this evening. High temperatures in the low thirties and humidex values near 40 have been observed this afternoon. Temperatures are expected to drop with showers lingering into this evening. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. During times of high heat, your health or your family and neighbours' health can deteriorate rapidly. The Ministere de la Sante et des services sociaux du Quebec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. Follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; avoid alcoholic beverages; if you can, spend at least 2 hours a day in an air-conditioned or cool location; take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; limit physical activity; wear light clothes. Be sure to: Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-20T06:10:25-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Some strong thunderstorms are developing over southern Alberta. These storms are capable of producing 2 cm hail, gusty winds to 90 km/h, and locally heavy downpours. These storms will dissipate later this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 50 knots, frequent lightning and waterspout activity are expected or occurring in the area. A line of thunderstorms has developed from Point Peele to Erieau, moving east at 35 knots. Squalls of 50 knots, torrential downpours suddenly reducing visibility to near zero and frequent lightning are likely with the strongest thunderstorms. There is also a potential for waterspout. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Isolated severe thunderstorms are likely this evening. Damaging hail near 3 centimetres in diameter and heavy downpours may be associated with thunderstorms. There is also a risk of a tornado. This line of severe thunderstorms is located from Moose Factory to 30 km north of Kapuskasing, moving east at 70 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for more squalls early this evening. While the risk of thunderstorms has diminished significantly there is a chance of thunderstorm redevelopment. Should thunderstorms develop they may be accompanied by wind gusts near 40 knots. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing large hail and heavy rain. Strong thunderstorms are expected to the west of Great Slave Lake. These storms can produce 2 cm or larger hail and locally heavy downpours. These storms are expected to dissipate later this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-20T08:04:04-00:00

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 50 knots, frequent lightning and waterspout activity are expected or occurring in the area. A line of thunderstorms has and is south of Point Peele to Erieau, moving east at 35 knots. Squalls of 45 knots, torrential downpours suddenly reducing visibility to near zero and frequent lightning are likely with the strongest thunderstorms. There is also a potential for waterspout. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
